Q: Show that the set $V = \Bigl\{ \matrixstart a & b \\ c & d \matrixend : a + b = 0 \land c - d = 0 \Bigr\}$ is a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^{2 \times 2}$.

A: Recall that the definition of a subspace requires three componenents:
(a) $0 \in V$.
(b) $u,v \in V \implies (u+v) \in V$.
(c) $r \in \mathbb{R}, u \in V \implies ru \in V$.

Working in order,
(a) Clearly $a = b = c = d = 0$ satisfies the restrictions on the set ($0 + 0 = 0 - 0 = 0$) and is the $0$ element of $\mathbb{R}^{2 \times 2}$.

$\therefore 0 \in V, \checkmark$.

(b) Let $u,v \in V = \matrixstart a_u & b_u \\ c_u & d_u \matrixend, \matrixstart a_u & b_v \\ c_v & d_v \matrixend$, respectively.

Then $u + v = \matrixstart a_u + a_v & b_u + b_v \\ c_u + c_v & d_u + d_v \matrixend$.

If $u + v$ satisfies the conditions on the set $V$, it will be in $V$.
$(a_u + a_v) + (b_u + b_v) = (a_u + b_u) + (a_v + b_v) = 0 + 0 = 0$.
$(c_u + c_v) - (d_u + d_v) = (c_u - d_u) + (c_v - d_v) = 0 + 0 = 0$.

$\therefore u+v \in V, \checkmark$.

(c) $r$ is a scalar in $\mathbb{R}, u \in V$.

Then $ru = \matrixstart ra & rb \\ rc & rd \matrixend$.

$ra + rb = r(a+b) = r0 = 0$.
$rc - rd = r(c-d) = r0 = 0$.

$\therefore ru \in V, \checkmark, \square$.
